text: Your sense of disgust became visible upon hearing of your client's sexually abusive acts toward a young child. It clearly showed by the grimace on your face and other nonverbal behavior. You should...
explanation: Once the nonverbal expression of disgust has occurred, this acknowledgment would be necessary to maintain genuineness. It can be done in a way that does not reject or judge the person who is the client. B is incorrect because it fails to accept the person. C is incorrect because the client will probably be aware of the reaction, even if the therapist suppresses her own knowledge of it. This approach would likely weaken the therapist's credibility with the client. D is incorrect for the same reason that C is incorrect.

text: Your depressed, middle aged client is an acculturated immigrant from Puerto Rico. He says that he is overwhelmed by a series of personal crises in the family and on the job. As a result he has been confused and anxious to the point where he fears that he might be going crazy. The first thing you should do is...
explanation: This answer describes the technique of partializing and prioritizing, an effective way to help clients in crisis to overcome the feeling of being overwhelmed. A is incorrect because you do not have enough information from the question to know if this client's reaction is within normal limits. For example, this client may be having this reaction because of an underlying personality disorder or because of a history of panic attacks (possibly indicated by the fear of going crazy). A would not be an appropriate response if these conditions applied. However, B would be an appropriate response under a wide variety of conditions. C is incorrect because you don't have enough information to know that medications might be needed. Not all clients who feel confused and anxious when under stress need to be referred for medications. D is incorrect because this kind of exploratory, interpretive therapy is not the best approach when clients are in crisis. A structured, supportive approach and directive role for the therapist would be better.

text: Mr. Carls came to see you at the family service agency seeking advice. He wants you to tell him whether he should eliminate his abusive daughter from his will or set up a trusteeship for her in the will. You should...
explanation: The client needs to know that legal advice is not something that a marriage and family therapist can offer, but he also needs to know what an MFT can offer that might be helpful in his troubled family situation. A and B are incorrect because they involve giving legal or financial advice. These functions are not within an MFT's scope of practice. D is incorrect because the client may need to see both an attorney and an MFT, not necessarily just one or the other.

text: Bob K. has been your client in individual therapy for the past 9 months, dealing with
explanation: Your pre-existing relationship with your individual client would create an unbalanced set of relationships. His wife would be new to you but your relationship with him would be well established. You would be going into these sessions knowing Bob's perspective on his wife, but not knowing her perspective on Bob. All of this would interfere with your ability to help Bob accomplish his purpose of resolving the money issue between him and his wife. A and B are incorrect for the reason that C is correct. D is incorrect because, even though Bob's request might be a resistance, you don't have enough information from the vignette to assume that this is the case.

text: Your client of three months informs you that she has been taking a tranquilizer for the past three months which was prescribed to her by her husband, a physician. She states that he is Board Certified and has other highly respected credentials in his field. You should...
explanation: Giving such advice is based on your familiarity with the limitations of your scope of practice. It addresses the issue of dual relationships without giving medication advice per se. B is incorrect because it involves giving medical advice, specifically, it involves the prescription of medications. C is incorrect because the husband is in a dual relationship with his wife, regardless of your judgment about his objectivity. Besides, it would likely be impractical to disrupt the flow of your therapeutic work with your client in order to have sufficient meetings with the husband and with the couple to make the judgment called for in answer C. D is incorrect because, even though it is not within an MP T's scope of practice to prescribe, dispense or administer medications, that doesn't mean that a marriage and family therapist may not address issues related to medications.

text: Your client, Mrs. T, asks if you would use "light trance work" in your sessions with her. You have not been trained in using this technique. However, you have experienced it yourself in experiential training workshops that you have attended and you feel familiar with the technique. You should...
explanation: The requested service is within an MFT's scope of practice, but it would constitute unprofessional conduct for you to engage in a practice for which you have not been adequately trained. A is incorrect because it is unprofessional conduct to engage in a practice for which you have not been trained even if the client agrees to it. This is the same principle that applies to a client's "consent" to have sexual relations with a therapist. It is unethical for the therapist, regardless of what the client says. C is incorrect because trancework is one of a wide variety of therapeutic techniques that is within an MFT's scope of practice with the appropriate training. D is incorrect because this client is only requesting a service, not determining it. If the MFT had been adequately trained in this technique the MFT could choose to accept the client's request.

text: Your client has been dealing with problems of emotional lability and passive aggressive behavior. When you confront the client with the statement that his anger toward his boss is self-destructive, he reminds you that you are the one who encouraged open expression of feelings in the first place. This client is challenging your...
explanation: Congruence refers to consistency. This client is saying that the therapist is being inconsistent. A is incorrect because the client is not complaining about the fact that you have encouraged him to behave in a certain manner, only that your encouragement has been inconsistent. B is incorrect because the client is not complaining about your having been judgmental. D is incorrect because scope of practice is not addressed in the question.

text: You are emphasizing the practice of accurate empathy in your work with Hal W, a twenty year old college student who has been struggling with autonomy and identity formation. The inferences you draw through your use of accurate empathy should...
explanation: Since empathic understanding is based on inference and use of one's imagination, feedback and verification from the client are needed in order to know if one's empathy is accurate. A is incorrect because, although empathy does use inference, the inferences need not be based on Psychodynamic Theory. B is incorrect because, although some therapists may need therapy in order to become sufficiently empathic, it is possible to be very empathic without any therapy at all. D is incorrect because accurate empathy may be experienced by the client as confrontive at times if the client is not ready to accept an aspect of his or her own thoughts and feelings.

text: A man and his wife never seem to see things eye to eye. When he judges something favorably, she judges the same thing negatively. When he decides that their best course of action is in one direction, she usually decides that their best course of action is to go in the opposite direction. According to Psychodynamic Theory these clients...
explanation: Psychodynamic Theory generally holds that individuals have some degree of ambivalence about most things. When two members of a couple each have difficulty accepting and integrating their own ambivalence, they each only accept one side of their feelings, with the other often projected or at least assumed by the partner. A is incorrect because individuals are not usually confused about their roles if 1 they are able to perform them regularly and reliably, as this couple is described. B is   incorrect because oedipal conflicts usually involve issues of guilt, anxiety and personal ideals. This couple appears to be on opposite ends of a wide variety of issues. C is incorrect because isolation as a defense involves the separation of thought from feeling. The issue in this question is more a matter of separating two sides of ambivalence.

text: Your client, Mr. P., initially came to see you for help with impulse control problems, including moderately assaultive encounters with co-workers. He has attended sessions regularly for three months. Now he comes up with reasons for missing every second or third session. You should take this as an indication of...
explanation: Missing sessions or coming late for sessions is generally considered to be an indicator of resistance to dealing with therapy or with difficult issues that are coming up in therapy. B is incorrect because, if the behavior is resistance, this would mean allowing the resistance to interfere with the therapeutic work. Besides, if this is resistance, then appointments would also be missed on the revised appointment schedule. C is incorrect because Mr. P might be hostile toward the therapist, but this would only be one of many possible reasons for the resistance. There is no specific evidence from the question that Mr. P is angry toward the therapist. His resistance might just as well be due to shame, anxiety or fear. A is a better answer. D is incorrect because Mr. P could be considered ready to terminate when his objectives have been met or when he has achieved the maximum level of therapeutic gain. There is no evidence of that in the question.

text: Your client, Terry Simmons, is a fifty year old divorced man who tells you that he has felt confused ever since his brother died in an automobile accident three months ago. If your objective is to encourage the client's deeper self-exploration, you should ask which of these questions?
explanation: This is the most open ended question. A is incorrect because it could be answered with "yes" or "no". That doesn't stimulate much self- exploration. C is incorrect because "why" questions usually call on clients to make causal inferences that they are unprepared to make. It leads to intellectualization and abstract analysis, not self-exploration. D is incorrect because it could be answered with "yes" or "no". You might need this information in conducting a psychosocial assessment, especially in formulating a diagnosis, but the question posed in D would not be as effective in encouraging deeper self-exploration as the question in B would be.

text: Your client meets criteria for an obsessive compulsive personality disorder. It would be reasonable to expect that this client will manifest which of the following behaviors during therapy sessions?
explanation: People with obsessive compulsive personality disorder have difficulty making decisions because of their characteristic perfectionism and preoccupation with irrelevant detail. It's as if no decision will ever be perfect enough, especially when one is confused by an overwhelming barrage of detail. A is incorrect because this is a quality you would expect from someone with histrionic or dependent. personality disorder, not an obsessive compulsive personality disorder. B is incorrect because it describes a true obsession. You would expect to find that in an obsessive compulsive disorder, but not in an obsessive compulsive personality disorder. D is incorrect because grandiosity is associated with narcissistic personality disorder or manic episode, not with obsessive compulsive personality disorder.

text: A client has revealed specific information that you are required by law to report. However, your supervisor insists that you refrain from reporting because of the agency's policy on confidentiality. You should...
explanation: Your obligation to make a mandated report is between you and the government authority that has issued the mandate. Agency policy does not override the law. You may not allow a supervisor to keep you from meeting your own legal obligations. C is incorrect because you would be required to make the report even if you were unable to gain your supervisor's agreement. D is incorrect because your reporting duty is clear. Consultation with attorneys should be saved for more complex legal matters.

text: You are using a Brief Psychotherapy approach with a highly motivated, psychologically minded client. The therapy will be insight oriented and focused on the identification and exploration of psychodynamics. You should...
explanation: A theme focus is the key to Psychodynamic Brief Therapy. A regressive flow of catharsis and exploration is more characteristic of open ended psychodynamic approaches. Therefore, A is incorrect. B is incorrect because the termination date and number of sessions should be specified, whether or not the objectives are achieved. If they are not, and the client still has a significant need for help, referral should be arranged to another resource. C is incorrect because brief therapy focuses on present issues and themes, not their initial causes. Initial causes may be pursued in open ended Psychodynamic Therapy.

text: A man calls to learn the current address of Mr. Anderson, one of your clients. He says that he is the executor of Mrs. Anderson's aunt's estate and that Mr. Anderson is due to receive a small inheritance. Which of the following statements should you make to the caller?
explanation: This statement does not reveal that you know a Mr. Anderson, nor does it reveal anything about him. It also gives Mr. Anderson an opportunity to find out about his inheritance, if the caller is legitimate. A is incorrect because it reveals that you know Mr. Anderson. C is incorrect for the same reason that A is incorrect. D is incorrect because it implies that Mr. Anderson is a client and it may serve to deny Mr. Anderson the opportunity to find out about his inheritance.

text: Glen and Maria have sought your help to resolve what they call "communication problems." Glen had an extramarital affair several years ago and speaks openly of his attraction to other women. Maria is hostile and highly critical of Glen in a sarcastic manner, but doesn't directly tell him how she feels or what she wants. In order to provide the most effective therapy for these marital problems you should use an approach involving...
explanation: This has been established in research. A is incorrect because there is little research evidence of the efficacy of individual therapy for solving marital problems. Besides, the term "primary cause" is a clue that the answer is incorrect. In family therapy it is generally assumed that no individual is a primary cause of a problem but that causation in family relationships is reciprocal. The problem is in the relationship, not in the person. C is incorrect because the efficacy of co-therapists over individual therapists has not been empirically established. D is incorrect because most behavioral therapy for marital problems is focused on operant (or voluntary) behaviors.

text: In reviewing your new client's previous clinical records you see that it repeatedly refers to your client's fsurvivor guilt." You should take this to mean...
explanation: A is incorrect, in part, because there is no evidence that serial killers feel guilt when a victim survives their assault. C is incorrect because, even though survivors of childhood sexual abuse do often feel guilty for their own victimization, this is not referred to as survivor guilt. D is incorrect because there is no particular psychological concept that applies to this situation. 18'. The correct answer is D because hypomanic symptoms are not associated with hypochondriasis. Notice the word "except" in the question. In hypochondriasis a great deal of anxiety is involved and all three qualities described in A through C are affected. See the DSM manual for more information.

text: For the past several years your client has been preoccupied with fears of having, or the idea that she actually has, a serious disease based on her misinterpretation of bodily symptoms. Her anxious preoccupation persists despite having been provided with appropriate medical reassurance. She is not delusional, but her preoccupation causes clinically significant distress. You should expect all of the following from this client except...

You ask the client "Could you describe what life was like in the family of your childhood?" The client responds "You want to know what I think about mainstream America, but what I really want to know about is this. Why must we have illness and disease when people are being blamed for nothing? Why? If I could get out of here I don't know what I would do." Your assessment should reflect the fact that this client is exhibiting...
explanation: Loose associations refers to speech in which ideas shift from one subject to another completely unrelated subject, without the speaker's awareness of the shift. A is incorrect because magical thinking is more coherent. It refers to the false belief that one's thoughts, words or actions can cause outcomes that are unrealistic. C is incorrect because mood congruent psychotic features refers to delusions or hallucinations which correspond to a person's depression or elation. D is incorrect because ideas of reference are beliefs that events, objects or other people in the immediate environment have a special, unusual meaning for oneself. Such ideas are usually expressed more coherently than loose associations, even though they are unfounded.

text: You are conducting a comprehensive clinical assessment with a woman of Asian ancestry who presents with a long history of derealization, paranoia, illusions, distortions, and magical thinking dating back to adolescence. The client also has difficulty modulating affect and uses primitive coping mechanisms. The most likely clinical problem experienced by this client is...
explanation: Personality disorder is indicated by the long history and by the variety of dysfunctional coping mechanisms and dysfunctional thought that is of less than psychotic proportions. Schizotypal, histrionic or borderline personality disorder are especially suggested by the symptoms listed. A is incorrect because there is no evidence of true psychotic features in the question. C is incorrect because the distorted thinking described by the question is not characteristic of generalized anxiety disorder, and the question does not specifically refer to the experience of anxiety. D is incorrect because the described disorderis long standing since adolescence and adjustment disorders do not lead to such extreme distortions in thinking. Often when people with personality disorders experience stress,however, their more usual distorted thinking is exacerbated. However, when that happens an adjustment disorder should not be diagnosed.

text: Your client is a fifty year old substance abuser whose marijuana and alcohol use began at age 11. As compared to other substance abusers, he has more psychiatric symptoms, and uses a wider variety of substances. Substance abusing clients such as this are more likely than other substance abusers to have a high prevalence of...
explanation: When substance abusers have personality disorders, their substance abuse tends to follow the pattern described in the question, that is, beginning at a young age, using a wide variety of substances, and having comorbid psychiatric symptoms. A is incorrect because the notion of a single addictive personality pattern has been discounted through research. B is incorrect because, although temporal lobe epilepsy can mimic the symptoms of a personality disorder, there is no connection to the substance abuse pattern described in the question. C is incorrect because the substance abuse pattern described in the question is not particularly related to those who abuse alcohol.

text: You receive several new referrals to treat individuals who have long standing, pervasive and inflexible personality patterns that significantly interfere with their psychosocial functioning. These traits include excessive suspiciousness, excessively strong emotional response to meaningless gestures by others, and extreme emotional lability. You should use any of the following interventions in the treatment of these clients except...
explanation: Notice the word "except" in the question. Provision of structure is an important element in clinical work with personality disorder clients. Client Centered Therapy is extremely open ended and unstructured in its format. A is incorrect because personality disorder clients often have crises that need to be handled. Crisis management provides a clear task focus and structure. C is incorrect because personality disorder clients can often change specific maladaptive behaviors, even when the fundamental character structure is unchanged. D is incorrect because, even though confrontations by the therapist are likely to be problematic, confrontation by peers in a self-help situation is often recommended by experts in this field of practice.

text: Micky, a seven year old boy of African American ancestry, refuses to go to school. He is willing to go with his mother, but when she leaves he cries hysterically until she returns and takes him with her. Your diagnostic assessment should view Micky's problem as...
explanation: You do not have enough information from the question to know whether or not this is a school phobia or a separation anxiety problem. If Micky is specifically afraid of being in school, even though he separates from his mother comfortably in other settings, then it would be a school phobia. If he is afraid of leaving his mother at school, at the local playground, at the babysitter's home, or anywhere else, then it would be a separation anxiety problem. D is incorrect because an eight year old child would normally have had at least two years of school experience and should have adapted to the school setting and to separation from parents.

text: All of the following kinds of clients might experience distractibility in the presence of anxiety arousing circumstances. Which ones should you expect to commonly experience distractibility in the absence of anxiety arousing circumstances?
explanation: Schizophrenia involves distractibility due to a fundamental deficit in selective inattention. People with other kinds of mental disorders might reduce their distractibility when treated with relaxation training or related psychophysiological stress management techniques. Distractibility in people with schizophrenia, however, does not substantially respond to such interventions. A is incorrect because avoidant personality disorder is not particularly associated with distractibility. C and D are incorrect because normal adults in either of these cultures are no more distractable than normal adults of other cultures.

text: You will be using a "psychosocial rehabilitation" approach to treat your agency's psychiatric clients with severe and persistent mental illnesses. In designing this program you should arrange to help the clients to do which of the following?
explanation: B is incorrect because, even though family relationships might be addressed in this approach, they are not as central to the focus and purpose of the approach as is job functioning. C is incorrect because the approach emphasizes placement in jobs within the general workforce, not in sheltered workshops. D is incorrect because the focus is on placing a person in a job and then learning job skills through on the job training. As compared to developmentally disabled clients, psychiatric clients generally leam their job skills relatively quickly. The rehabilitation focus is on helping the clients learn to apply social skills to master problems that arise in the workplace culture and through interpersonal demands.

text: If a marriage and family therapist has a sexual relationship with a former client whose therapy was terminated three years ago...
explanation: The AAMFT Code of Ethics allows for sexual relationships with former clients if at least two years have elapsed following termination. However, under these circumstances "the burden shifts to the therapist to demonstrate that there has been no exploitation or injury to the former client or to the client's immediate family." A is incorrect because California state law also allows for sexual relationships with former clients if at least two years have elapsed following termination. B is incorrect because the therapist has a burden to demonstrate that there has been no exploitation or injury to the former client or to the client's immediate family. The therapist would not have this burden in sexual relationships with other individuals. D is incorrect because there is no requirement that the therapist document that the relationship would not be harmful. The therapist's burden to demonstrate that there has been no exploitation or injury essentially applies in situations where the former client or an authorized representative of the former client claims that the relationship is harmful. The client would not have to prove that it was harmful, but the therapist would have to prove that it wasnlt harmful.

text: In your work as a patient services counselor in a medical setting you are treating several patients who deny their depression. They complain of problems such as headache, aches and pains around joints, backache, and fatigue, yet there is no physiological or physical basis for these complaints. You should view these clients as having... .
explanation: B is incorrect because a psychosomatic disorder is a true physical illness caused by or exacerbated by a psychological problem. This causal or exacerbating quality is not described in the question. C is incorrect because a factitious disorder involves the voluntary production of a symptom. The question does not raise this issue. D is incorrect because, even though the fatigue referred to in the question might be associated with psychomotor retardation, the other symptoms are not necessarily related.

text: Your client's record shows that he has been successfully treated with electroconvulsive therapy. This client probably has a history of...
explanation: Note the word "probably" in the question. Electroconvulsive therapy is used to treat severe depression, not the other conditions listed in the question.

text: Some of your severely depressed clients have been treated only with pharmacotherapy and psychotherapy, whereas other clients have also been treated with electroconvulsive therapy. As compared to your other clients, those who have been treated with ECT are more likely to experience...
explanation: Research has also shown that the risk of morbidity and mortality in the medically ill and elderly patient may actually be lower with ECT than with pharmacotherapy.

text: Your client complains of lapses in attention and concentration that have caused problems on the job. The client reports two recent minor auto accidents and says that marital discord has been increasing over the past year. He says, "She complains about my snoring. She complains about my gaining weight. She just complains." You should refer your client for a medical evaluation to be checked for...
explanation: Obstructive sleep apnea syndrome is referred to as a "breathing-related sleep disorder" in DSM terminology. It involves multiple sleep interruptions due to blockage of the air passages. Reference to snoring is a clue. B is incorrect because this disorder, formerly known as a sleep-wake cycle disorder, involves the lack of a patterned time for falling asleep and waking from day to day. The symptoms described in the question suggest a lack of sleep, not this sleep schedule problem. C is incorrect because, even though the lapses in attention and concentration could be due to this disorder, the other features are much more likely to be associated with sleep apnea syndrome. D is incorrect because pica involves the repetitive eating of non-nutritive substances.

text: You are assessing relationship patterns in a family with a rebellious adolescent son and two younger daughters. Dysfunctional communication in the family has reached a steady state. You should expect that the dysfunctional communication patterns in this family will have all of the following characteristics except... ,
explanation: Notice the word "except" in the question. Steady state refers to a system's tendency to maintain behavior within a given range of variation. It is associated with homeostasis, a flexible balance achieved by maintaining behavior patterns within a range. However, these patterns may eventually shift toward either a healthy or unhealthy position as time goes on. A is incorrect because all system members play a role in maintaining the system's patterns. B is incorrect because a system's behavior patterns could not persist if they did not serve a function for the family as a whole, even though the effect might be problematic for one or more individuals in the family. C is incorrect because, even though steady state leads to a stable balance, this is not a rigid balance. Unlike "equilibrium," homeostasis does allow for some degree of change as circumstances change.

text: You are conducting an assessment with an 83 year old client who has recently been given a pair of crutches. Which of the following would be the most appropriate thing for you to say if you needed to know about the adequacy of the client's crutches?
explanation: Note the words "most appropriate" in the question. A is incorrect because it is a double question. It asks about two issues at the same time. Such questions are confusing to clients. C is incorrect because it is a leading question. It influences the client to provide the answer that the interviewer favors. D is incorrect because it is too vague. If your purpose is to find out how well the client's crutches are working out you don't need to hear the client's comments about the aesthetics of the crutches' wood grain or how the crutches remind him of the ones used by his grandfather.

text: You are leading a support group at a hospital. While discussing a client's reaction to the recent death of her husband, one of the clients says "And what about you? Have you ever lost someone so close?" Assuming that you have experienced such a loss, your best response would be...
explanation: Note the word "best" in the question. In classical psychoanalysis where the therapist takes the position of a blank screen, something more akin to A, B or C might be in order. In the kind of situation described by the question, however, the best response is one that provides a simple, direct answer, then directs the focus back to the client as soon as possible.

text: You are interviewing a new client who reveals that her husband has severely beaten her in the past, to the point where she once had to be hospitalized for a fracture. The abuse abated for a while, but over the past two weeks he has begun to shove her and throw things at her. You should inform the client about all of the following except...
explanation: Notice the word "except" in the question. B holds the woman responsible for her own abuse. Nobody does anything that causes another person to physically assault them. The abuser is responsible for acting abusively. A is incorrect. It helps to reduce guilt and self-blame. C is incorrect. It confirms that there is social support over such abuse and that society holds the perpetrator responsible. D is incorrect. It helps to universalize and, again, mitigates against self-blame. In other words, A, C and D are all things that should be said to an abused woman.

text: Your client is a 33 year old woman with schizophrenia who is very stable when she takes her antipsychotic medications regularly. However, she occasionally neglects to take her pills because she either forgets or overestimates her recovery. When this happens she rapidly becomes delusional, suicidal and needs hospitalization. This client could most benefit from...
explanation: Injectable medications are longer lasting than oral medications and the client's stability would not depend on her remembering or choosing to regularly take medications. A is incorrect because electroconvulsive therapy (shock therapy) is a treatment for depression, not schizophrenia. B is incorrect because this would not be as reliably effective as the injectable medications. Also, since the client's noncompliance is due, in part, to an overestimation of her recovery, she might decide that she didn't need to attend the rehabilitation program any more than she needed to take the medications. D is incorrect because this approach would not be as reliably effective as injectable medications. The risk of rapid decompensation is too great in this case. However, if the client's decompensation was more gradual and suicide was not such a high risk, behavior modification might be sufficient to improve the client's medication compliance.

text: Your client has a long history of dysthymic disorder. She complains of various somatic ailments but does not consider herself to be sad or to have a depressed mood. She seeks help in adapting to a new job with a domineering supervisor because she fears that she will "lose my cool in front of him and be out of a job." She says that she does not want to deal with long term personality change. You should focus your approach to this case on...
explanation: This is closest to the service requested by the client. B is incorrect because the client explicitly does not want to work on personality change. Also, her ability to cope with the problem she presents can be improved without making major personality change. C is incorrect because advice should be given sparingly and only when necessary. There is no indication from the question that this would be necessary. D is incorrect because it describes an approach that would be appropriate for long-term personality oriented therapy, not for the problem solving focus that the client is seeking and needing.

text: When tracking the psychodynamic themes of your therapy group's process, you see counterdependents and defenders emerge during the exploring and testing phase. These group members' roles refer to the stance they take in relation to...
explanation: In this question, reference to dependency in the term "counterdependents" might be taken as a clue, since the therapist is the person most likely to be viewed as the caretaker and leader during this early phase of group development.

text: In your insight oriented, intensive psychotherapy group, you should expect that realistic (non-transference) sources of rebellion against you as the therapist might arise for all of the following reasons except one. Which one?
explanation: Notice the word "except" in the question. All effective group therapists need to assume a position of authoritative (not authoritarian) leadership. Rebellion against such constructive and functional leadership would generally be viewed as a transference, not a realistic reaction. A, B, and C are all realistic and problematic sources of frustration for group members.

text: You are forming an intensive psychotherapy group at a community mental health clinic. The group's purpose will be personality reconstruction. In deciding who to admit to your group, you should exclude clients who are...
explanation: Note the word "exclude" in the question. A is the only set, where all three elements are true; that is, all three should be excluded from such a therapy group. B is incorrect because neurotic clients do not need to be excluded. C is incorrect because physical disability has no bearing on a person's capacity to benefit from intensive, reconstructive group psychotherapy. D is incorrect because none of these diagnoses need to be excluded.

text: Your new clients' previous therapist used Satir's Conjoint Family Therapy. These clients probably learned from their previous therapist that marital problems result from...
explanation: A is more associated with Minuchin's Structural Family Therapy. B is more associated with psychodynamic approaches to family therapy. Any approach to family therapy might actually deal with unresolved, covert sexual conflicts, but it is not a key feature of Conjoint Family Therapy. C is a better answer. D is more associated with Murray Bowen's Intergenerational Family Therapy.

text: You are leading a psychoeducational group for parents of elementary school age children with behavior problems. They all have significant dysfunctional communication patterns within the family. In teaching these parents to communicate more effectively with their children, you should...
explanation: Communication skills, like any other behaviors, are most rapidly and effectively learned through demonstration, practice, and feedback. B, C and D are incorrect because, even though these procedures can lead to positive growth, they have not been demonstrated to be as efficient and effective for learning new skills. B can lead to insight without behavior change. C can lead to positive growth but there is no focus on communication skills. Communication skills may or may not be among the clients' priorities for change as self-actualization develops. D may be effective if it is part of the demonstration used in the A sequence of demonstrate, practice and feedback. Otherwise the client may not identify with the therapist as a model, or the client may want to be like the model but, without an opportunity to practice and get feedback, may miss the mark.

text: You are seeing a family in which a teenage son got his ear pierced. As a result, the mother became deeply depressed, shouting "how could you do this to me?" The father broke a piece of furniture in anger, proclaiming "you'll have the neighbors talking about us for months". You should View this family as...
explanation: This family is enmeshed because family members are unnecessarily emotionally reactive to one member's behavior, and without an adequate sense of boundaries and autonomy. A is incorrect because, in a disengaged family, members are minimally responsive to one another. B is incorrect because the question doesn't directly describe any dependency or codependency issues. D is incorrect because in order to depict inflexible structure the question would have had to describe the family over a period of time. Their structure would be inflexible if it did not change as needed when significant family events occurred such as the birth of an infant, the emancipation of a son or daughter, or the death of a family member.

text: Mrs. K. complains that her twelve year old son, Daniel, has been hostile and disrespectful to his parents, and to other adults as well, ever since he was a toddler. Both she and her husband are willing to work with you in family therapy, "as long as you can show him how to become a decent and respectful person." In your Social Systems Approach to family therapy you should view this symptom bearing child as...
explanation: Jay Haley, and other family therapists, note that a social system is composed of mutually influencing and interrelated members. All members influence one another. This includes the "identified patient" or symptom bearer. Cause- effect relationships are reciprocal. They do not begin with any one member and end with any one other member. Therefore, B and C are incorrect. The symptom bearer is not simply the victim or scapegoat of others. He or she is a participant in a mutual process. D is incorrect because family therapy focuses on the family group, not on society, even though it recognizes society as a family system's environment.

text: Your client is an anxious, self-depreciating 17 year old girl. She has been struggling with the issue of psychological separation from her family. She says that she loves her parents very much, and that she doesn't want to hurt them, but she adds that "I need to live my own life and I just don't see things the way they do." The treatment method of choice is...
explanation: A and B are incorrect because family therapy of any kind is contraindicated for an older adolescent whose issue is psychological separation from the family. D is incorrect because residential treatment is best suited to more severe pathology where a structured and protective living environment is needed. Group therapy might be helpful with this kind of client, but it is not listed here. Individual therapy is the best option of the choices available.

text: Your colleague, a psychologist, refers his former client to you. It appears that his reason for terminating the client is to enter into a sexual relationship with her. You may...
explanation: Both the AAMFT Code of Ethics and state law prohibit you from paying compensation, monetary or otherwise, in exchange for a referral. However, state law specifically allows you to collaborate with a referral source, and to charge the client a fee for the collaboration as long as the client has been informed prior to the commencement of therapy about this fee practice, and nothing in the code of ethics prohibits a marriage and family therapist from doing so. B is incorrect because such a fee is explicitly allowed in state law and is not prohibited in the code of ethics. C is incorrect because both state law and the code of ethics prohibit you from compensating a referral source for a referral. Both monetary and non-monetary compensations are prohibited. D is incorrect because there is no reason to refuse the referral. The psychologist is acting unethically if he is terminating treatment for the purpose of entering into a sexual relationship with his former client, but this should not prohibit the client from receiving services hom another therapist, even if the referral came from the psychologist.

text: Your client is an otherwise healthy and well functioning woman who has recently survived a major natural disaster. She lost her home in another state, and moved to California "to get away from it all? Now she is homeless, lacks a local social support network, and feels "overwhelmed by all these problems? "This is hopeless," she says. "I don't know where to begin? Your treatment approach with this client should be...
explanation: B is incorrect because, even though the therapist should be warm and empathic, she should be directive rather than exploratory. C is incorrect because the therapist need not be charismatic and should not be dramatic. D is incorrect because the therapist should be directive rather than exploratory, and active rather than passive.

text: Your comprehensive clinical assessments of your clients should be...
explanation: In marriage and family therapy practice, all aspects of the process -- including assessment, treatment planning, interventions and termination -- should be conducted in a therapeutic manner. A client can gain a great deal of learning and insight through participating in a well developed assessment process. A is incorrect because survey research techniques are used for gathering descriptive data from large samples. There is no direct connection to comprehensive psychosocial assessment. C is incorrect because the assessment is the basis for formulating a treatment plan, not the outcome of a treatment plan. D is incorrect because the length of an assessment depends on the nature of the client and problem. Also, assessment is considered to be an ongoing process.

text: In using accurate empathy with an extremely fearful client you will need to use...
explanation: By definition, empathy means using one's imagination to put oneself into the psychological frame of reference of another person. Accurate empathy, then, involves sharing your imaginative insights with the client for confirmation and feedback about its accuracy. B is incorrect because, although fantasy may be the product of imagination, it usually has a defensive or need gratifying purpose. Defensiveness and need gratification are not a part of the empathic process. C is incorrect because empathy involves intellect, emotions, and images. Technical skill tends to focus on intellect and behavior. D is incorrect because it too refers to intellectual knowledge.

text: In working with clients from Latino cultures you should anticipate that all of the following will tend to be true except...
explanation: Note the words "tend" and "except" in the question. Latino cultures emphasize the organic wholeness of mind and body. B through D are incorrect because they all tend to be true in Latino cultures, although each individual and each family need to be assessed for their unique qualities within the culture.

text: Your new client, a middle aged man with a long history of self-doubt and disturbed sense of identity, reports that he has been in psychotherapy before over a three year period with a Gestalt therapist. In the course of receiving Gestalt therapy this client has probably learned to view psychopathology as...
explanation: Most Gestalt Therapy techniques are geared toward helping an individual become aware of a fuller range of their experiences. Often that means becoming more aware of ambivalences. The goal is greater self-acceptance and better integration of the whole (i.e. the gestalt). B is incorrect because it is more characteristic of the psychoanalytic view of psychopathology. C is incorrect because Gestalt Therapy does recognize psychopathology. D is incorrect because it is more characteristic of Behavior Modification.

text: Bill K. was hospitalized in a psychiatric setting following a dramatic suicide attempt. He treats some of the staff as ideally compassionate and others as callous or malevolent. You should recognize Bill's way of relating with hospital staff as...
explanation: A is incorrect because there is no evidence of intentionally manipulating staff to achieve a specific goal. B is incorrect because there is no evidence that Bill identifies with hospital staff. C is incorrect because psychic numbing refers to a reduction in general responsiveness to environmental stimuli. There is no evidence of that here.

text: Which diagnosis would you expect to be most likely for a person who has made a dramatic suicide attempt and, when hospitalized, treats some of the staff as ideally compassionate and others as callous or malevolent?
explanation: Note the words "most likely" in the question. Splitting is characteristic of the borderline personality disorder. It is not particularly characteristic of the other diagnoses listed.

text: Your former client's husband requests help in dealing with his sense of insecurity and social anxiety. If you were to use a Gestalt therapy approach you would be basing interventions on concepts and principles drawn from...
explanation: A is incorrect because, even though much of Humanistic Psychology borrows psychoanalytic concepts, the focus is on an individual's inherent capacity to grow and solve problems if they are provided with therapeutic conditions. This is different than Psychoanalytic Theory which relies more heavily on a therapist's insights into a client's psychodynamics, insights which are conveyed to the client through interpretation. C is incorrect because Gestalt Therapy gives little attention to the specific, observable reinforcement contingencies that shape behavior. D is incorrect because Rankian Psychology is a form of Psychoanalytic Theory.

text: Your client reveals that he has burglarized a neighbor's house to obtain a piece of jewelry that he has always admired. You...
explanation: State law regarding confidentiality and privileged communication does not allow for such a revelation except in specifically defined compelling circumstances. The law does not require you to report crimes sue . as burglary. If your client consents to your report of his crime, you may then reveal the information if you feel it would be in his best interest. In such circumstances it would be best, of course, to encourage the client to make his own report rather than doing it for him. B is incorrect because you may reveal confidential information, even information about a crime, with a client's consent. C is incorrect because California does not require reports of crimes such as burglary, even though it requires reports of crimes involving abuse of children, elders or dependent adults. D is incorrect because you may not report a his crime without his consent.

text: You are conducting a psychoeducational workshop where one of the members complains that she used to be blamed for causing her son's psychotic symptoms, but now she has learned that schizophrenia is caused by genetic defects. You should inform this person that recent research demonstrates that genetic abnormalities...
explanation: If one identical twin develops schizophrenia, the sibling will not necessarily develop schizophrenia. Therefore, their identical genetics do not cause the condition. However, the twin sibling has a greater chance of developing schizophrenia than does an unrelated person in the general population. That's because the genetic predisposition contributes to the condition. It creates a vulnerability to schizophrenia. C is incorrect because the term "exacerbate" refers to a condition becoming worse once it has been diagnosed. Therefore, a stressful event that happens during the course of someone's schizophrenia might exacerbate the schizophrenia, but genetic changes aren't likely to happen during midlife.

text: Your client is a deeply depressed college student, age twenty, who has just begun to take tricyclic antidepressant medication. She says that she has taken her medications for one week now but "they're not working. I don"t feel any different." How long should this client continue to take her medication to determine whether or not it is effective?
explanation: Some antidepressants are faster acting. Tricyclic antidepressants, however, require four to six weeks for sufficient blood levels to cause clinically observable change.

text: As a marriage and family therapist you have an ethical responsibility to obtain appropriate informed consent to therapy as early as feasible in the therapeutic relationship. The AAMFT Code of Ethics approach to informed consent includes all of the following except...
explanation: The marriage and family therapy profession's code of ethics does not require that clients be made aware of alternative services which could meet their needs. The important thing is that the client understands the treatment they are being offered and consents to that treatment. A and D are incorrect because these qualities are fundamental requirements of all ethical and legal approaches to the concept of informed consent. C is incorrect because the client must be informed of potential risks and benefits of treatments for which generally recognized standards do not yet exist. The AAMFT Code of Ethics does not require that a client be informed of potential risks and benefits of treatments for which generally recognized standards do exist. A cautious approach to this standard would take"generally recognized standards" to mean standards that are recognized by the general public as well as by professionals.

text: Your client has sought your help in resolving communication problems with her husband. The issue has been a problem since their marriage 10 years ago. Your assessment reveals that neither the client nor her husband meet the criteria for a DSM diagnosis, but you believe that you could make a case for an adjustment disorder diagnosis.
explanation: It is unethical to distort or misuse clinical findings. If you believe that neither the client nor her husband meet the criteria for a DSM diagnosis, as the question stipulates, then you should not put effort into trying to make a case for a DSM diagnosis, not for the purpose of obtaining payment nor for any other reason. A is 60'. The correct answer is MISSING. 61'. The correct answer is MISSING. 62'. The correct answer is MISSING. 63'. The correct answer is MISSING.

text: Your client's thinking has a magical quality. Wishes are perceived as real and are equated with deeds. She invests her wishes, thoughts, and dreams with concrete reality because she is unable to understand the personal nature of these abstractions. She has recently internalized an image of her mother and has achieved object constancy, that is, her experience of her mother's presence in her life is not dependent on the mother's physical presence. You should view this individual as presenting features that are developmentally appropriate for...
A Marriage and Family Therapy Internis supervisor has asked to observe one of her interviews with a client. The intern should...

You are conducting an assessment interview with a highly verbal, articulate and psychologically minded client. In the course of conducting your assessment interview, important facts about the client are available to you through...

You will be working with three adult members of a family together in a series of family therapy sessions. They are a married couple and the husbands father. What should be your approach to maintaining confidentiality among family members?
Marriage and family therapists have an ethical responsibility to...
explanation: The AAMFT Code of Ethics states that "marriage and family therapists encourage public participation in the design and delivery of professional services and in the regulation of practitioners." A is incorrect because such public participation should be encouraged, not discouraged. B is incorrect because the ethical standard specifically calls for participation by the public. It is not limited to encouraging participation by other members of the profession. D is incorrect because this issue is addressed in the professions code of ethics.

text: A disheveled and depressed person with schizophrenia applies to your mental health clinic with the following request. "I'm ready to find a good job, get married, and settle down for a change." Initially, you should...
explanation: Note the word "best" in the question. What does the person mean by "a good job"? What does the person mean by "settle down for a change"? B is incorrect because a marriage and family therapist should begin where the client is and respect the client's right to self-determination. The client's request is what the client is motivated to do something about. C is incorrect because you don't know enough about the person yet to give realistic reassurance. D is incorrect because such a goal might be realistic, depending on what the person means by the request and depending on the kinds of therapeutic and socially supportive services that can be provided.

text: You are establishing a new private practice and you are seeking referrals for clients who might benefit from short term, interpretive psychotherapy. In order to achieve a positive response in using short term, interpretive psychotherapy it is most important that you...
explanation: Note the words "most important" in the question. A positive response to short term therapy usually requires the ability to enter into a close relationship (with the therapist) in a short period of time, as well as the ability to tolerate the anxiety aroused by confrontation and rapid change. B is incorrect because neither conscience nor ego ideal, the two aspects of superego, are necessarily at issue in short term therapy. C is incorrect because "short term, interpretive psychotherapy" is psychodynamic, not behavioral, in nature. D is incorrect because the question asks about what short term, interpretive psychotherapy requires. The therapist's charisma might help, but it is not required for a positive response from the client.

text: Mr. Lambrosky, a 64 year old retired carpenter, asks you to meet with him and his wife. He says, "I think we need financial counseling or something." He says that his wife insists on mounting debt whereas he is very concerned about protecting funds for their future. During the initial session you should...
explanation: Keep in mind that the question asks what you should do in the initial session. Also note that B says that you will be meeting with the couple "to review the way they are approaching their financial situation." A is incorrect because, even though there does appear to be a relationship problem here, that problem will need to be addressed in later sessions. Initially you should begin where the client is. C is incorrect because the client doesn't appear to be asking for technical advice about bookkeeping or investment strategies. He is asking for help with the way he and his Wife make decisions together. C is also incorrect because it uses the term "redirect," suggesting that the client would be offered a referral to a financial consultant instead of being able to see a marriage and family therapist. D is incorrect because the initial session is much too soon for this sort of assessment, especially in View of the client's request and presenting problem.

text: Your client is a 28 year old Asian woman who rarely makes eye contact with you during your initial session. You should recognize that this client's avoidance of eye contact may be an expression of...
explanation: Avoidance of eye contact is an expression of cultural norms for many, but not all, Asian people. However, a person of any culture might also avert their eyes if they are shy, they have recently done something for which they feel shameful or guilty, or if they feel intimidated by the person they are with.

text: As a marriage and family therapist you should not engage in sexual relationships with clients...
explanation: A is incorrect because the unequal power and authority inherent in the therapist/ client relationship means that a decision about this kind of relationship cannot truly be mutual on an equal, non-coercive basis. Also A through C are all incorrect because they all involve dual relationships of one kind or another. For example, a marriage and family therapist should not have their spouse for a client.

text: Your approach to psychotherapy with anxiety disorder clients has been effective, yet you have given very little, if any attention to the initial cause of your clients presenting problems. Your approach is probably based on which of the following theories?
explanation: Practice approaches guided by Behavioral Theory are focused on the current sustaining conditions of a behavior, not the original cause. The other approaches listed are, however, concerned with understanding initial causes -- even going back to early childhood experiences -- as well as current sustaining conditions. Psychotherapy based on psychodynamic Ego Psychology theory gives less attention to initial causes of a problem than either classical Psychoanalysis or psychotherapy based on Self Psychology. However, Ego Psychology based approaches are more likely to address these issues than the approaches based on Behavioral Theory.

text: Which of the following criteria would be most relevant when determining which of several possible treatment goals and objectives to pursue in your work with a client in crisis?
explanation: You have an ethical obligation to use only methods that are within your scope of competence and a legal obligation to use only methods that are within your scope of practice. If the client needs help in achieving other goals that cannot be achieved using methods within your scope of practice and competence, the client should be referred out for such help. A is incorrect because the most important goals might not be the one's that can be achieved in the shortest amount of time. B is incorrect because the client may need to, and want to, pay out of pocket to work on goals that are not within the parameter of his or her insurance coverage. D is incorrect because the theoretical approach should be selected according to the client's individualized assessment findings. Cognitive behavioral therapy has demonstrated efficacy in treating certain problems with certain kinds of clients. It is not necessarily the best approach to use in any situation.

text: As a Licensed Marriage and Family Therapist you are supervising a Marriage and Family Therapy Intern who is concerned that most of her clients feel anxious during early therapy sessions. You should help her understand that anxiety during initial sessions...
explanation: Anxiety can motivate change if it is not overwhelming and debilitating. The stem of the question does not say that the client's anxiety is overwhelming. A is incorrect because it uses the term "always." Although you should reduce anxiety through support and reassurance if the anxiety is interfering with therapy, you should not reduce it in this manner if it is contributing to therapy. C is incorrect because the stem of the question does not say that the anxiety is overwhelming. D is incorrect because most people feel anxious during early therapy sessions, regardless of their character structure. Clients are anxious because they are entering a relationship with a stranger, revealing sensitive thoughts and feelings, and unsure about their prospects for resolving the problem that brought them to therapy.

text: You have been treating a client for a variety of psychosocial problems stemming from the clients medical condition. During four years as your client she has gone through extended periods of stability with little to talk about during sessions. At other times when she does have issues that are troubling her, she has sometimes become guarded and quiet during sessions. The treatment has been approached in an open ended manner, with no predetermined time frames set for termination. You should recommend termination of services to this client when...
explanation: The AAMFT Code of Ethics states that "Marriage and family therapists continue therapeutic relationships only so long as it is reasonably clear that clients are benefitting from the relationship." A is incorrect because, even though a client has the right to terminate at any time, you are not obliged to recommend termination whenever a client requests termination. A client who still needs service may request termination due to ambivalence or resistance to change. In such instances you should help the client understand the underlying motivation and inform the client of the possible consequences of termination. B is incorrect because client resistance is common and can be worked through. D is incorrect because countertransferences are common and can also be resolved.

text: Geri G. is a fifty-five year old woman who has been hospitalized for treatment of fractures and a concussion following an automobile accident. She calls you, her former therapist at a family service agency, to complain about the poor arrangements by hospital social service staff for her return home. You should...
explanation: There is no reason to believe that the client is unable to resolve the problem directly with her current hospital social worker. Getting involved could lead to triangulation and confusion. B is incorrect because of the reason just stated. C is incorrect because it simply calls on the client to accept an inadequate discharge plan instead of encouraging the client to work toward a more satisfactory plan. D is incorrect because it is tangential to the presenting problem.

text: Your client engages in a variety of pathological behaviors. She sees her symptoms as ego dystonic in that they don't make any sense to her. She can't understand why she acts the way she does, and she doesn't want to continue acting the way she does. Which of the following should you expect to be this client's most likely diagnostic category?
explanation: Obsessions and compulsions are, by definition, ego dystonic. A is incorrect because people with personality disorders don't experience their character traits as problematic or ego alien. C is incorrect because, even though people with substance use disorders will, from time to time, be troubled by their addiction and want to quit, they are more characteristically in denial. They View their compulsive pattern of substance use as something that they want for themselves. D is incorrect because factitious disorder is voluntarily initiated. People with factitious disorder see the symptoms as something they want to be doing.

text: A young man complains to you that he has only been sleeping five hours a night, but .feels that he needs a full eight hours of sleep to feel rested. He also is concerned that he has gradually been withdrawing from friends and family, that he is disinterested in his usual activities, and that he has been feeling fatigued. Your first activity should be to...
explanation: The symptoms suggest clinically significant depression. Suicide risk is associated with depression and risks should be addressed first in an assessment. A through Care incorrect because, even though these things should be done, they should not be "your first activity."

text: Your new client is a forty-six year old man who came to see you because "I'm afraid I 'm going crazy." Two weeks ago he began to hear voices telling him about terrible things that are about to happen. He firmly holds a false belief about his wife trying to poison him. He believes the voices are as real. He has never experienced psychotic symptoms before they began two weeks ago. You should anticipate that this client will most probably...
explanation: Your client's condition is probably a brief psychosis. It is probably not schizophrenia (which typically first occurs during the second and third decades of life) or a psychotic disorder due to a general medical condition (in which the psychotic features do not usually occur suddenly). When brief psychoses go into remission the person returns to their previous level of functioning.

text: Joe G. is a new client, age thirty-three, who has been feeling confused and emotionally distraught since his close friend died of AIDS three weeks ago. He was very . dependent on his friend for advice, emotional support, and financial support. He is troubled because he now feels fall alone and I don't know what to do." You should...
explanation: A client first coming to you in crisis will derive a sense of realistic reassurance from this kind of structure. C is incorrect because "authoritarian" involves an unquestioning obedience to authority, rather than individual freedom of judgment and action. "Authoritative," on the other hand, refers to competent authority based on qualifications, knowledge, skill and expertise. D is incorrect because you can't begin where the client is if you don't focus on the crisis. Acknowledge the client's strengths as they become apparent, but not as a way of avoiding or minimizing the crisis. A is incorrect because, especially with a new client, you don't know if the problem will be resolved. You only know that it can be resolved.

text: Your client is a 65 year old woman who reveals to you that her alcoholic husband is treating her in a way that meets the criteria for mental suffering under the Elder and Dependent Adult Abuse Act. Which of the following is true?
explanation: The Elder and Dependent Adult Abuse Reporting Act requires a report if you have a reasonable suspicion that physical abuse, isolation, abduction, fiduciary abuse, or neglect have occurred. The law permits but does not require a report regarding mental suffering. The AAMFT Code of Ethics states that "Marriage and family therapists do not disclose client confidences except by written authorization or waiver, or where, mandated or permitted by law." Therefore the code of ethics also permits but does not require a report in this situation. A is incorrect because a report of mental suffering is optional, not mandated, under the law. C is incorrect because the code of ethics allows you to disclose client information where permitted by law. D is incorrect because the code of ethics permits you to disclose client information by making the report, but it doesn't require you to do so.

text: As a marriage and family therapist you receive referrals from physicians and nurses who are seeking your psychosocial assessments of their major surgery patients. They ask that you pay special attention to these patients' judgment, object relations, cognitive functioning and perception. Which of the following factors should you consider to be least relevant to assessing these issues?
explanation: Note the word "least" in the question. A is incorrect because a person's developmental stage is always relevant to assessing ego functioning. For example, you wouldn't expect to find the same level of judgment, abstract thinking, or calculation ability in a three year old as you would in a forty year old. C is incorrect because reality testing is an ego function, therefore it is relevant to assessing ego functioning. D is incorrect because culture shapes the way in which we express our ego functions. For example, when assessing the ego function of object relations we need to remember that some cultures support independence and others support mutual dependence. When assessing the ego function of judgment we need to remember that some cultures support risk taking, others support minimizing risks. In general, you would expect to find strong similarities between two forty year old men and women of a particular culture. You would expect to find strong dissimilarities between a five year old and forty year old. You would expect to find strong dissimilarities between a sub- Saharan farmer and a New York City stockbroker.

text: You are on the staff of a residential treatment program. Another staff member asks you if you can help her understand your client's behavior and wants to know if you have any suggestions for helping him in a group she is leading. In View of your client's legal rights to confidentiality you should...
explanation: Both federal and state law, and ethical standards, allow information to be shared among staff of a facility or program, even without the client's permission. However, the profession's code of ethics and federal HIPAA regulations require that the client be informed of such practices in writing. B is incorrect because the law and ethical standards do allow you to discuss your client with a fellow staff member at a program. C is incorrect because you do not have a duty to confirm the confidentiality commitment of your colleagues. D is incorrect because the colleague does not need to obtain such a written release from the client. This would be required if you were in a private practice and the requesting party was not an associate of your private practice, but it is not required in the situation described by this question.

text: One of your private practice clients, a 40 year old insurance salesman with major depressive disorder, has been seeing you on a fee-for-service basis. Although the client has sufficient resources, he has failed to pay an overdue balance. It would be ethical for you to terminate services to this client due to his failure to make payment...
explanation: You may terminate a client with an overdue balance, and there is no prohibition against doing so, as long as the termination is done in a way that does not constitute client abandonment. The most ethical approach to this issue is one in which you have previously informed the client that this would be the consequence of an overdue balance, you've determined that the client is not at imminent risk, and the consequences of failure to make payment have been discussed with the client. B is incorrect because the payment is already overdue. The client has already failed to keep a previous promise regarding payment for services. C is incorrect because the client may not need another therapist, or may not need one to be readily available. This would depend on the client's clinical condition. D is incorrect because termination is ethically . permissible under the conditions described above.

text: Your client's primary purpose in seeing you has been to reduce anxiety, especially involving autonomic hyperactivity, and agitation. After working together for four months you learn that your client has been using amphetamines almost daily for the last nine months. The first thing you should do is to...
explanation: Since the client's primary purpose is to reduce anxiety and agitation, any therapeutic interventions to accomplish this goal while the client is still using amphetamines would be ineffective and wasteful. You should not, however, abandon the client. If termination became necessary you should make the client aware of the appropriate resources for assistance in overcoming an amphetamine addiction. B is incorrect because it compounds the client's chemical dependency by adding another drug without resolving the dependency problem. C is incorrect because the client's thinking will be distorted as long as he is using amphetamines. Insight will be impaired by denial and confusion arising from the effects of the amphetamines. D is incorrect because you don't know that this client has a need for such intensive medical support during detoxification and there is no specific evidence that the conditions for a medically necessary hospitalization are met.

text: You have been treating a depressed man with a history of severe impulse control problems. He has been in trouble with the law over the years, partly due to domestic violence. A court of law has now ordered you to disclose confidential information about the client, but when you inform the client of this he says that he refuses to give consent. In your clinical judgment, disclosure of the requested information could cause harm to the client. You should do any one of the following except...
explanation: Note the word "except" in the question. The law and the Code of Ethics require you to take any one of the three actions described in A, B and C. It does not require you to involve the client in what may become a tense relationship between yourself and the court. Also, keep in mind that this client has not consented to reveal the information. It would be unethical for you to deal with your obligation to the court by asking a person whom you know to be an unwilling participant to carry out your responsibility.

text: Your client is a fifty year old man who is in recovery from an alcohol addiction which has been a problem since age 10. He is concerned about a persistent problem of guilt. He avoids competition and is righteously moralistic when referring to successful people he knows. What developmental age would most likely be the source of the client's underlying conflict or fixation?
explanation: This is a question about Erikson's developmental framework. These are qualities that are established in personality during the stage of initiative vs. guilt, which corresponds to Freud's Oedipal stage, and which occurs between the ages of about four through six.

text: In which of the following clients would you be least likely to find psychotic symptoms? The client with...
explanation: Note the word "least" in the question. In A, B and D psychotic symptoms are prominent and defining features. Schizotypal personality disorders, however, may not involve the experience of psychotic symptoms and these symptoms are not among the defining features of the disorder.

text: Your client has been in therapy with you for 10 months. The primary goal is to eliminate the client's panic attacks which are due to a panic disorder. There has been no change in the client's frequency or intensity of panic attacks since initiating therapy. You should...
explanation: Research evidence shows that panic attacks due to panic disorder can be resolved in as little as three or four months when the appropriate treatment method is used. After 10 months of no progress you should either change your treatment method or, if you are using a method that should be effective, refer the client to another therapist. This would be consistent with the AAMFT ethical standard which states "Marriage and family therapists continue therapeutic relationships only so long as it is reasonably clear that clients are benefitting from the relationship." A is incorrect because there is usually no good reason to provide more of something that hasn't been effective. B is incorrect because a change of treatment methodology might be sufficient to improve effectiveness. This approach could take advantage of any therapeutic alliance that has been established. C is incorrect because there is no evidence that intensive process oriented group psychotherapy is an effective means of eliminating panic attacks due to panic disorder. C is also incorrect because it doesn't address the need for you to change your approach.

text: Mr. K is a 39 year old man who sought therapy for help with a long standing pattern of self-defeating behavior. He also complains of emotional lability and a series of unstable relationships with women. He is now divorced from his second wife. In conducting a clinical assessment with Mr. K you should...
explanation: An understanding of the client's developmental past is one way of better understanding the client's present personality. Also, your understanding of a client's past can help you communicate with clients when they speak about memories of the past and their current thoughts and feelings about those memories. B would be correct if all marriage and family therapists used a behavioral approach. However, since a rich variety of theories are used, and since exam questions are usually not based on a particular theory unless specified, you should pay attention to this client's early developmental experiences. They might be very important to the client and may help the client understand current motivations and conflicts. This is especially relevant in a case like this Where the client sees his problem as something more than simple behavior patterns. C is incorrect because, in marriage and family therapy practice, attention is given to early experiences primarily as a way of understanding the present. D is incorrect because diagnosis of mental disorder is based on current symptom patterns, not on etiology or initial causative experiences.

text: When using clinical case material for purposes of teaching...
explanation: It is rarely necessary for students to know the identity of a client when the client's case material is being presented for teaching purposes. A is incorrect because you wouldnlt need such a confidentiality commitment if you took sufficient steps to protect the client's identity. Even after taking such steps, it is a good idea to ask students to treat the information confidentially just in case they or others recognize a subtle identifying feature that you have overlooked, but the fundamental protection is not the students' confidentiality commitment...it is the steps you take to protect the clients identity.
