Your anxious client is scheduled for an amputation of the left leg in three days. You can help your client reduce the stress resulting from her surgery by.
explanation: Anticipatory guidance is widely recognized as an effective means of reducing stress reactions to predictable stressors. A is incorrect because you cannot effectively and significantly build a person's self-esteem in three days. C is incorrect because this would be false assurance. You don't really know if the person will be able to handle the stress effectively. D is incorrect because, even though some psychological conditions might warrant postponement of surgery, simple anxiety is not sufficient cause. Most everyone is anxious in anticipation of surgery.

text: When working with clients in a stress reduction clinic, you should help your clients understand that all of the following have been found to reduce the level of stress experienced by a person except for the person's...
explanation: Note the word "except" in the question. Level of education doesn't help a person manage stress. B is incorrect because our sense of adequacy and worthiness lead to confidence and the ability to cope with stress. C is incorrect because the very purpose of ego defenses is to manage anxiety, including the anxiety that results from stress. D is incorrect because understanding the nature of a stressful situation gives a person a sense of control, a "cognitive grasp" as it is referred to in the crisis intervention literature.

text: Section 5150 of the Welfare and Institutions Code...
explanation: The law states that "When any person, as a result of mental disorder, is a danger to others, or to himself or herself, or gravely disabled, a peace officer, member of the attending staff, as defined by regulation, of an evaluation facility designated by the county, designated members of a mobile crisis team provided by Section 5651.7, or other professional person designated by the county may, upon probable cause, take, or cause to be taken, the person into custody and place him or her in a facility designated by the county and approved by the State Department of Mental Health as a facility for 72-hour treatment and evaluation." A is incorrect because the law does not authorize any marriage and family therapist to involuntarily hold a person. The MFT must be specially designated, for example by virtue of being on the staff of a mobile crisis team. C is incorrect because any peace officer may involuntarily hold an individual under this law if the peace officer believes the person to be a danger due to a mental disorder. The assumption regarding the mental disorder does not need to be confirmed by a mental health professional. D is incorrect because only certain designated mental health professionals may hold a person involuntarily, regardless of the opinion of a peace officer.

text: Your client has recently experienced a severe trauma. She was the victim of an attempted rape but was saved when a police car happened to drive by the scene by chance. The perpetrator fled but your client was severely distressed by the assault. Your therapeutic approach should include all of the following elements except...
explanation: Note the word "except" in the question. While you should accept the client's expressions of anger and even retribution if that's what the client is thinking and feeling, you should not encourage such expression. B is incorrect. You should be supportive rather than confrontive. C is incorrect. You should allow the client to repeatedly talk about the trauma. This can be used as the basis for developing a sense of understanding and restoring a sense of control. D is incorrect. This intervention can serve to protect the client's health and help her maintain the stamina needed for effective therapeutic engagement.

text: Your clinical assessments and treatment plans should recognize that one of the following emotions has been found to be especially highly conditionable, that is, readily transferred to previously neutral stimuli. Which one?
explanation: Note the word "especially" in the question. Fear and anxiety are exceptionally subject to conditioning and to being transferred (generalized) to previously neutral stimuli.

text: Your clients, a married couple, came to therapy claiming that "we need to improve our communication." Early assessment revealed a problem of recurrent violent outbursts on the part of both partners. By the fourth month the couple has shown some improvement but violent outbursts continue and are now described as "open expressions of anger." Suddenly both partners say that they have achieved their goal in therapy and want to terminate. You should take this to mean that your clients are experiencing...
explanation: Resistance and flight into health often occur in the middle phase of therapy. It is a way of avoiding the increasingly difficult issues that arise after early defenses are worked through. A is incorrect because the request to terminate came suddenly and without a substantial resolution of the clients' major problem. C is incorrect because no specific evidence of this is provided in the vignette. D is incorrect because countertransference refers to the therapist's thought, feelings and/or behavior, not the client's.

text: You have been asked to develop diagnostic formulations of family dynamics as a consultant to a group of pediatricians. Among other issues they have asked you to identify patterns of enmeshment or disengagement. These are problems of family system...
explanation: Enmeshment and disengagement are problems of resonance. In enmeshment family members are much too responsive to one another's thoughts, feelings and actions. They resonate or react to the slightest cue, thereby interfering with the autonomy of individual family members. In disengagement there is very little resonance to one another, even when important issues are raised by a family member. A is incorrect because family systems are not designed. They arise and grow through natural development, not intentional planning. B is incorrect because a family's resonance relates to any issue in family life, not just authority issues. D is incorrect because enmeshment and disengagement are more directly related to family process or dynamics rather than structure.

text: Your client has been depressed over a series of what she calls "failed relationships" in which she has been subject to exploitation and scapegoating. Your client's goal is to reduce depression and improve her sense of confidence. You should recommend that the treatment plan include, as appropriate objectives, any of the following except...
explanation: Note the word "except" in the question. Free floating anxiety is not directly related to depression, self-doubt or vulnerability to exploitation by others. In any case, it is not as directly related as are the other three qualities listed: self- assertion skills, self-esteem and self-acceptance.

text: Your depressed client has threatened suicide and claims that she intends to take an overdose of sleeping pills, prescribed by her internist, sometime within the next few days. She has made such threats before on three occasions over the past two years. She has made one ineffective suicide attempt which you consider to have been an attempt to gain attention and dependency. Which of the following should be your first course of action?
explanation: The client's threat should be taken seriously, especially because she is depressed, has a specific plan, has the means to carry it out, and expresses an immediate intention to act within the next few days. B is incorrect because it does not address the risk. C is incorrect because it does not address the risk sufficiently. Under these circumstances even three or four outpatient sessions per week might not provide sufficient monitoring. D is incorrect because an abrupt termination would constitute client abandonment and because you should be able to manage a suicide risk, in collaboration with others such as the psychiatrist.

text: You suggest termination to a client with whom you've been working for 9 months because she has substantially reached her primary goals and objectives. You should expect that her termination will be least likely to give rise to which of the following conditions?
explanation: There is no need to renegotiate the treatment plan if primary goals and objectives have been achieved. If the client seeks to renegotiate at this point, it is probably a regression and will serve as an opportunity to learn about how the client handles loss. Termination is a loss and, if sufficient time is allotted to work it through, clients can learn skills in coping with loss during the termination process (A). Also, client regression often occurs at termination as a way of trying to reverse the decision and maintain the relationship (B). Finally, if a client takes the termination as a rejection, the client is apt to find ways to reject the therapist in return, perhaps by devaluing the therapist and expressing hostility (C). A

text: You are working with a bereavement support group. The members are free of diagnosable mental disorders but could benefit from supportive services. Which of the following symptoms would you not expect to find among these clients who are experiencing normal bereavement?
explanation: A is incorrect because it is not unusual for survivors to hear the voice or sense the presence of the deceased. B is incorrect because depression is perhaps the most characteristic symptom of bereavement. D is incorrect because agitation often expresses the survivor's anxiety and attempts to create distractions from his or her depressing thoughts. C may occur in bereavement, but it is not as characteristic as are the other symptoms listed. Impaired immediate recall is a sign of organic mental disorder.

text: You are working with a thirty-two year old male, African American client with paranoid schizophrenia. You should consider which of the following to be the least helpful intervention for this client if he has recently become depressed after being evicted from his apartment for loud outbursts in the middle of the night?
explanation: Note the words "least helpful" in the question. A Interpretive psychotherapy is usually to be avoided in work with clients who have schizophrenia. The abstract nature of interpretive inferences are confusing to the thought disordered client. Confronting defenses may also be unnecessarily threatening, especially to a client who is paranoid. Case management is needed to provide social support and assistance in obtaining resources and an alternative living arrangement (A). Medications may be needed to restore impulse control and control the symptoms that likely led to the late night outbursts (B). Psychosocial rehabilitation may also be needed to learn better ways of coping with stresses that may have led to the outbursts (D). Also, this client may need help in an apartment search and in negotiating relationships with a new landlord and neighbors.

text: Your new client states that he has sought psychotherapy because he strives for a greater capacity for intimacy. In the course of your work with this client, which of the following developmental issues should you address first?
explanation: The stage of intimacy vs. isolation immediately follows the stage of identity vs. identity diffusion or role diffusion. Erikson explains that in order to feel the security needed to risk one's identity by fusing it with that of another person, one must first feel secure in one's own identity. B is incorrect because the developmental issue of generativity vs. stagnation follows intimacy vs. isolation. Generativity becomes possible once we have learned to enter into the intimate relationships that make it possible to generate families, projects and careers. C is incorrect because the question is based on an Eriksonian conceptual framework. Erikson does not focus on such Freudian psychosexual issues as the Oedipal conflict. D is incorrect because Erikson's theory is not a theory of psychotherapy. He does not prescribe the method for achieving growth and development. Instead, he focuses on describing the sequence of issues that must be addressed as a person grows and develops.

text: Your client is a forty-five year old business manager who would like to develop a greater capacity for self-assertive behavior in social relationships. In order to monitor the clients eventual progress you should first establish a baseline by measuring which of the following?
explanation: Frequency refers to how often the behavior occurs. Magnitude refers to the strength or intensity of the behavior. Duration refers to how long the behavior lasts when it does occur. B is incorrect because it ignores duration. Magnitude and intensity mean essentially the same thing. C is incorrect because motivation, capacity and situation opportunities are three important aspects of all clinical assessments, but they are not particularly relevant to establishing a behavioral baseline. These concepts are too abstract to serve as a basis for setting a behavioral baseline. D is incorrect because it only refers to frequency, not magnitude and duration.

text: In the course of developing greater self-assertive skills with your forty-five year old client, you will be using behavioral rehearsal. Your approach should involve all of the following techniques except...
explanation: Behavioral rehearsal is similar to role playing. First the therapist describes or demonstrates the desired behavior. Then the client practices what has been taught. Then the client is provided with feedback and reward for desired behaviors. Extinction may occur, as with any learned behavior, but it is not part of the behavioral rehearsal procedure.

text: You are using a Cognitive Behavioral approach to therapy in which you and the client will be working to modify dysfunctional automatic thoughts. Your work will involve...
explanation: The same principles of both operant and respondent learning apply to thoughts as they do to behavior. A is incorrect because psychoactive medications may alter one's thoughts, but they are not usually directly used as part of the cognitive therapy process. C is incorrect because, although operant conditioning may be used, it is only one of many techniques. B is a better answer because it is more inclusive. D is incorrect because, although reward is used in cognitive behavioral therapy, punishment (or aversive stimuli) may be used as well.

text: A new client has requested that you use the technique of flooding in his treatment. He explains that he has a friend whose therapist has used this technique very successfully. You should explain to the client that flooding may or may not be an appropriate technique to use in his treatment, depending on the nature of his problem, and that flooding is best used to...
explanation: In flooding, the client is presented with stimuli that are associated with anxiety for long periods of time until they lose their capacity to evoke anxiety. A is incorrect because depression due to misconceptions is best treated with cognitive restructuring techniques. C is incorrect because flooding is usually used to eliminate a problematic behavior, including anxiety. Acquiring assertion skills is best accomplished through instructional techniques, modeling and behavioral rehearsal. D is incorrect because the disorientation in a person with delirium is biologically caused and the underlying biological dysfunction needs to be treated medically.

text: You will be engaging a client in a time limited exploration of the client's unconscious psychodynamic conflicts. Your work with this client should be characterized by all of the following principles except one. Which one?
explanation: Note the word "except" in the question. Sifneos and Malan, two leading proponents of the psychodynamic approach to brief therapy, state that the therapist must be able to simultaneously provide and balance confrontation and support. They do not call on the therapist to emphasize one over the other. The principles addressed in A, B and D are all key elements in this approach to therapy.

text: You are working with a variety of clients who are new immigrants from Asian and Pacific Islander cultures. Many of these clients have been treated by indigenous healers in their native land, and some continue to see indigenous healers in your community. You will probably find that these healers seek to...
explanation: Conditions that might be viewed as mental illness in Western cultures may be viewed as a disharmony between mind, body and spirit in Asian and Pacific Islander cultures. Indigenous healing practices seek to restore this harmony. A is incorrect because self-control and emotional restraint are valued. Use of will power and suppression of disturbing thoughts is likely to be sought, rather than encouraging their catharsis. C is incorrect because a sense of intergenerational dependence tends to be valued, and is not seen as a cause of psychic distress or social dysfunction. D is incorrect because indigenous healers are just as likely to be concerned with relieving distress as with enhancing social functioning.

text: Prior to entering into a therapeutic relationship with your client you have an ethical obligation to clearly disclose and explain all of the following except one. Which one is the exception?
explanation: The requirements stated in answers A, C and D are all clearly stated in the AAMFT Code of Ethics Sec. 7.2. B is the correct answer because you have no formal ethical obligation to justify your fee to the client. The client is free to accept or reject the fee.

text: You are working with a client in long term, insight oriented Psychodynamic Psychotherapy in which the purpose of therapy is improved psychodynamic efficiency. This means that you and the client will be working toward...
explanation: Improved efficiency means obtaining better results for less expenditure of energy. B is incorrect because psychic energy which is invested in either conflicts or fixations is inefficiently directed away from obtaining gratification in the real world. C is incorrect because Psychodynamic Psychotherapy may seek to bring preconscious material into consciousness, but this is not directly related to the concept of improved efficiency. D is incorrect because the concept of "improved efficiency" refers to a much broader array of issues than rapid development of a therapeutic alliance. This is only one example of how psychic energy might be efficiently invested.

text: Your client becomes agitated and angry when you confront her with a discrepancy. Last week she told you that she was raised by her grandparents and today she told you that she was raised by her mother and stepfather. She now denies ever saying that she was raised by her grandparents. You should...
explanation: A is incorrect because your client would simply claim that your notes were inaccurate. Also, it is likely that the treatment relationship would not be enhanced at a time like this by reminding the client that you are writing notes about them after every session. C is incorrect because it is not a genuine response. D is incorrect because the interpretation would not be very effective at this point in time while the client is denying that she is being deceptive. B is genuine without being overbearing on the client.

text: You are interviewing a client who has a difficult time focusing on a specific problem or any specific issue. The client's comments tend to be vague, general and indirect. If you wanted to develop better focus in the interview, which of the following kinds of comments should you make?
explanation: Closed questions and requests for descriptions tend to result in better focused answers. Open ended questions and requests for speculation, inferences and impressions tend to result in less focused answers. They are useful for engaging clients in deeper self-exploration but not for focus. A is an open ended question. B is an indirect question because it begs the same kind of response as an open ended question would. D is an even more broadly worded question than A. C is a more specific, and therefore delimited, request for a description of a day at work.

text: In offering Rational Emotive Therapy to a client with a major depressive disorder, you will be...
explanation: After "disputing" the client's false beliefs through rational confrontation, homework assignments are used to break negative behavior patterns and self-reinforcement is taught through learning covert self-statements, more constructive statements that clients learn to make to themselves. B is incorrect because, in R.E.T, the therapist disputes the beliefs and confronts the client with their invalidity rather than focusing on the client's need to maintain the belief. C is incorrect because the false beliefs are disputed before new beliefs are offered in their place. D is incorrect because R.E.T. focuses on the way in which thought causes emotions, not the other way around.

text: You must make a child abuse report only if you develop a reasonable suspicion that child abuse has occurred as a result of information that you have received...
explanation: Note the word "only" in the question. The Child Abuse Reporting Law states that a marriage and family therapist must report if you have "knowledge of or observe a child in his or her professional capacity or within the scope of his or her employment..." A is incorrect because your reasonable suspicion may be based on information from any source. B is incorrect for the same reason. D is incorrect information obtained in the course of private, personal relationships.

text: A primary care physician has requested that you provide a consultation involving a thorough DSM Cultural Formulation. Your report back to the requestor should address all of the following issues except one. Which one?
explanation: Note the word "except" in the question. The cultural identity of the client's significant others is not specifically addressed by the DSM framework for a Cultural Formulation, and it would be unethical to reveal information that is not needed to accomplish the purpose of the request. In order to determine the cultural identity of others the therapist would need to interview those others. This would be an expensive and cumbersome process. Most of the focus of the Cultural Formulation is on the client's experience of his or her own cultural reference group and what is known about the culture in general.

text: A mother comes to see you with her nine year old daughter. She reveals that her husband has been fondling their daughter for the past six months. She wants you to meet with her husband and "give him the help he needs." Your first course of action should be to...
explanation: This approach offers to empower the mother if she is ready to take that step. If not, then the therapist should make the call to protect the daughter and to comply with legal mandates. A is incorrect because it fosters an aura of secrecy and distance between therapist and client. C is incorrect because this action would be too stressful for most nine year olds in this situation and because the therapist doesn't have the authority to insist that the mother make the call. D is incorrect because it fails to offer the mother the opportunity to take a positive action on her daughter's, and her own, behalf.

text: A marriage and family therapist is a covered entity under federal HIPAA regulations if the MFT...
explanation: HIPAA regulations apply to any health care provider who engages in one or more electronic transmissions of private client information. This does not include telephone communications, or communications from one fax machine to another, but it does include communications between a fax machine and a computer. B is incorrect because paper records alone would not qualify a marriage and family therapist as a HIPAA covered entity. C is incorrect because submission of claims to an insurance plan would only qualify the therapist as a covered entity if communications of client information with the insurance plan were made by electronic means. D is incorrect because a single electronic transmission regarding a single client would qualify the therapist as a covered entity, regardless of the total number of clients served.

text: Your client is a Latino man with a major depressive disorder. He tells you that he has seen a curandero who has also treated many others in his family. In his work with the curandero, you should expect to find that this client has likely experienced which of the following techniques?
explanation: Curanderos typically have the aim of bringing the individual closer to the spiritual and religious culture of the Roman Catholic church. They do not generally practice exorcism or witchcraft. They do commonly use massage, cupping, "cleansing" rituals, herb remedies, prayer, advice, confession and reassurance.

text: Your new client is an anxious and guilt ridden thirty-five year old fashion designer who is cautious about entering into new relationships. She also exhibits signs of a social phobia. In order to develop a therapeutic alliance with this client, which of the following should you use in the first few sessions?
explanation: These three qualities are specifically designed to provide a therapeutic relationship process. They can be offered before a great deal of assessment information has been gathered. B is incorrect because during the first few sessions you don't know the client well enough to offer sound advice or realistic reassurance about the presenting problem. C is incorrect because these techniques will require considerable exposure prematurely. This is often associated with a sense of embarrassment, shame and premature termination. D is incorrect because confrontations and interpretations should generally wait until after a therapeutic alliance is established and the therapist has enough information about the client's personality and life situation to be able to make interpretations accurate, meaningful and well timed.

text: Your new client is an anxious and guilt ridden thirty-five year old who has worked with several other therapists over the years. She feels that therapy has benefitted her, but that it never seems to be enough. She would like you to discuss possible adjunctive therapies if she is to begin work with you. Which of the following modalities should you consider as an appropriate adjunct to your psychotherapeutic work with this client?
explanation: Biofeedback teaches a person to enhance their own alpha waves which are associated with relaxation. A is incorrect because electroconvulsive therapy, or shock therapy, is used to treat depression. B is incorrect because antabuse is an agonist therapy for treatment of alcoholism. D is incorrect because lithium carbonate is used to treat manic episodes in a bipolar disorder.

text: Your client Bill G., a deeply depressed man, has been contemplating suicide. His risk is moderate and not imminent at the moment. Your approach to Bill should include all of the following except one. Which one?
explanation: Note the word "except" in the question. You should be prepared to increase the frequency of visits or to set ad hoc appointments; also be available by phone and arrange for back up or crisis service contacts available when you are not. All other techniques noted should be used with suicidal clients.

text: Your new client is a sixty five year old woman who was recently found to be the victim of isolation. This means that she has probably been subjected to...
explanation: Isolation generally includes any intentional act that serves to separate the individual from others against his or her will. It includes preventing the dependent or elder adult from receiving mail or phone calls, falsely telling prospective visitors that the person is not present, false imprisonment, or physical restraint for the purpose of preventing a meeting with visitors. B is incorrect because it describes "neglect," not "isolation." C is incorrect because quarantine performed pursuant to a physician's instructions is explicitly excluded from the law regarding isolation. D is incorrect because physical restraint for the purpose of punishment is "physical abuse," not "isolation." See Sections 1510.43 through 1510.63 of the California Welfare and Institutions Code.

text: In taking a Humanistic Existential approach to your depressed and anxious middle aged client, you will be focusing on...
explanation: These theories prescribe such experiences as self- congruence and empathic understanding. They speak of "implementation of an attitude" rather than specific techniques. A is incorrect because these approaches deemphasize treatment planning and prescribe no particular planning techniques. C is incorrect because, again, the focus is what attitude a therapist should assume, not what a therapist should do in a procedural sense. D is incorrect because the Humanistic Existential therapist does not interpret a client's dreams, as a psychoanalytic therapist might do.

text: You are about to form a new Gestalt Therapy group. In the course of your pregroup interviews you should inform them that they should follow all but one of the following principles when participating in the group. Which one?
explanation: Note the words "all but one" in the question. Gestalt Therapy is focused on experience, not intellectual analysis. A is incorrect because acceptance of responsibility is a core value in that it contributes to developing a sense of integrity or wholeness. B is incorrect because risk taking is a core value. It refers to letting go of archaic response patterns and allowing new ones to emerge in the present circumstances. D is incorrect because this principle is a core value in all Humanistic Existential psychotherapies, including Gestalt.

text: In the course of your long term, insight oriented therapy with a thirty-four year old psychologically sophisticated Latina client, which of the following is most likely to serve as a realistic, non-transference source of rebellion...
explanation: Ambiguous and covert promises are dysfunctional communication patterns which would arouse frustration, anger and rebellion in most people. These are not considered transference reactions because they are not based on distortions brought to the current relationship by the client as a result of past experiences with others. B is incorrect because advice and direction are not a standard practice in many approaches to psychotherapy. If the client has sought psychotherapy and if these limitations are clearly explained to the client during early sessions, rebellion against this limitation would be an unrealistic transference. C and D are incorrect for the same reason that B is incorrect. They reflect standard psychotherapy practices which the client is free to accept or reject by terminating the psychotherapy relationship.

text: You are teaching the anxious and overbearing parents of an unruly five year old child to use negative reinforcement as a way of improving the child's behavior. This means that you will be teaching your clients to...
explanation: Many people confuse "negative reinforcement" with punishment. Negative reinforcement creates a positive experience for the individual by removing something that had previously been aversive, annoying, or painful. For example, if a child has been confined to his room until he finishes his homework, by allowing the child to leave his room when homework is finished he has been negatively I reinforced. Eliminating a previously imposed punishment constitutes negative reenforcement. B is incorrect because it describes punishment, not negative reinforcement. C is incorrect for reasons noted above. D is incorrect because anticipatory guidance involves instruction and rational discussion, not specifically reinforcement.

text: You are conducting a cognitive assessment as part of a mental status exam for your new client, a seventy-year old woman living in a nursing home. When you ask the client "How many nickels are there in $1.35?" you are testing for...
explanation: When conducting a mental status exam, calculation questions test a person's ability to concentrate and focus attention through the steps of the calculation. But the client's fund of information is being tested as well. If a client had never learned how to divide, good concentration and attention span will not produce the correct answer. That's why B is incorrect. C is incorrect because level of consciousness refers to a person's capacity to focus and shift, as well as maintain attention. A client's degree of alertness and wakefulness should be apparent from simple interview questions and would not require a calculation test. D is incorrect because recent memory refers to a person's ability to recall information over a period of several hours to several days. Tests of calculation require use of memory, primarily immediate retention and recall, not recent memory.

text: You are reviewing the clinical record of a new client, a seventy-year old woman who lives in a nursing home. The clinical record of her mental status exam states that she is "oriented times three." You should take this to mean that...
explanation: A is incorrect because "oriented times three" refers to a person's orientation at a point in time, not over the course of time. B is incorrect because orientation to procedure is not an aspect of the mental status exam. A person may be asked to follow a set of procedures, such as arranging matchsticks in a particular geometric pattern, but this is a test for apraxia or disturbed executive function, not orientation. D is incorrect because, although these are mental status exam issues, they are not matters of orientation.

text: As an MFT working in a county operated mental health service system, the consent of the client must be obtained before sharing confidential information with...
explanation: This awkwardly worded requirement is found in Welfare and Institutions Code Section 5328 which governs confidentiality in public mental health service systems. The law states that information and records shall be disclosed only in certain situations. Among them is this. "In communications between qualified professional persons in the provision of services or appropriate referrals, or in the course of conservatorship proceedings." The law then places a restriction on communications between certain professional persons. The consent of the patient, or his or her guardian or conservator shall be obtained before information or records may be disclosed by a professional person employed by a facility to a professional person not employed by the facility who does not have the medical or psychological responsibility for the patient's care? A and B are incorrect because the law allows sharing of confidential information among staff of a program and even staff of a service system, as long as the client is informed at the outset of treatment that such sharing of information is the practice. D is incorrect because information may be shared, even without the client's consent, when the receiving person has medical or psychological responsibility for the client. The clients consent must be obtained before sharing information with others who do not have medical or psychological responsibility for the client.

text: In the course of developing treatment plans with your clients you are guided by principles drawn from Solution Focused Therapy, in which a client's well formed goals should have presence, not absence. Your treatment plan goals should be similar to which of the following examples?
explanation: Presence means that goals should be stated in the affirmative, indicating what should be present when the goal is achieved. Feeling relaxed is what is present when anxiety is reduced. B is incorrect because both "increase confidence" and "improve self esteem" are examples of presence. C is incorrect because both "improve social skills" and "improve quality of social relationships" are also examples of presence. D is incorrect because "reduce anxiety" is an example of absence, not presence. Also, "increase self-assertion skills" is an example of presence, not absence.

text: You are working with a cyclothymic client whose depressed moods are clearly associated with dysfunctional automatic thoughts. In order to assist the client to modify these automatic thoughts using Cognitive Therapy you should first use which of the following techniques?
explanation: Thought recording is a technique used for identifying automatic thoughts. These thoughts must first be identified before the evidence for their validity can be examined (B), or before alternatives can be generated (A). C is incorrect because reattribution is also an intervention technique used to correct erroneous attributions of cause-effect relationships.

text: As a staff member in a county mental health service system, if a client consents to the release of confidential information to a designated person, the MFT...
explanation: The Welfare and Institutions Code Sec. 5328 states that confidential information shall be disclosed only under certain conditions. Among them is this. "When the patient, with the approval of the...licensed marriage and family therapist, who is in charge of the patient, designates persons to whom information or records may be released, except that nothing in this article shall be construed to compel a...licensed marriage and family therapist...or other professional person to reveal information that has been given to him or her in confidence by members of a patient's family." A is incorrect because most public mental health clients are clinically and legally competent to give informed consent, and approval by a family member is not necessary. C is incorrect because the therapist may release the information but is not compelled to do so. Clients often give consent to release more information than is necessary to release in order to accomplish the clients own purpose. D is incorrect because most clients are presumed to be competent. A formal documented evaluation is not required every time the client gives consent, unless there are indicators that the individual might not be competent.

text: Your 21 year old client is preoccupied with trying to determine the subtle motives of authority figures, including professors and her employer. Her preoccupation stems from an unresolved fixation arising from her relationship with an exploitive and harsh foster parent during her elementary school years. This client's fixation involves a problem of...
explanation: Cathexis refers to the way in which psychic energy becomes invested in a particular object or issue. A fixation is a cathexis that remains long after there is any adaptive purpose to the investment of psychic energy. A is incorrect because secondary process thinking refers to logical and reality oriented thinking. B is incorrect because psychic structure refers to the id, ego and superego. A fixation is not a structure but a process. D is incorrect because the superego is the aspect of the mind concerned with conscience or morality as it was learned in childhood. Fixations may or may not become established due to morality concerns.

text: Your client is troubled by a sense of emptiness, identity confusion, and the meaninglessness of life. From the perspective of Psychosynthesis, a Humanistic Existential Psychotherapy approach, you should help your client to achieve...
explanation: Dis-identification from all that is not the authentic self means giving up the distortions of defensiveness and false identifications with fragmented or partial aspects of self. A is incorrect because repression of the sublime refers to the failure to accept and manifest our highest nature. It is something to be overcome, not to be achieved in therapy. C is incorrect because the concept of mobile fixations is an inherently contradictory combination of concepts from Psychodynamic Theory. D is incorrect because unconditional positive regard is a quality the therapist must bring to the therapeutic process. It is not necessarily a goal for the client to achieve.

text: You are providing crisis intervention services following a major earthquake. Your clients are middle class and working class individuals whose homes were lost, either due to fires or because their homes are now structurally unsound. In working with these clients you should not...
explanation: Note the words "should not" in the question. The therapist should genuinely accept the unique and special quality and benefits of a crisis intervention approach. A is incorrect because a client's defenses generally should be accepted and supported, not challenged, in crisis intervention therapy, as long as they serve to contain anxiety without disabling the client. B is incorrect because crisis intervention does not seek to achieve fundamental personality change or elimination of clinical syndromes. The focus is on restoring functioning to the precrisis level. C is incorrect because crisis intervention does seek to develop a cognitive grasp of what otherwise might feel like an overwhelming situation. This is done by helping a client to partialize and prioritize elements of the crisis.

text: Your 12 year old client reveals that she has been severely beaten by her uncle who lives with her and her parents, and you have a reasonable suspicion that she has been abused. When making a telephone report of child abuse in this case, which of the following information must you provide to the child protective agency?
explanation: Section 11167 of the California Penal Code requires that the mandated reporter provide information about "the name, address, telephone number, and other relevant personal information about the person or persons who might have abused or neglected the child", if known. A is incorrect because the law requires you to report "the child's name, the child's address, present location, and, if applicable, school, grade, and class" but not the child's diagnosis. B is incorrect because reporting requirements apply to the individual reporter, and the reporter's supervisor is irrelevant to the child protective agency. D is incorrect because the reporting law says nothing about the reporter's license number.

text: When working with clients at the senior mental health clinic, you will be required to make reports under the elder abuse provisions of the law whenever you obtain reliable reports from your clients that they have experienced any of the following conditions except one. Which one?
explanation: Note the word "except" in the question. California law states that "abuse of an elder or a dependent adult" means physical abuse, neglect, fiduciary abuse, abandonment, isolation ,abduction, or other treatment with resulting physical harm or pain or mental suffering..." A, B and C are incorrect because they are specifically mentioned in the law. D, fraud, is not included. Even though fraud may be illegal according to other laws, it is not specifically illegal as elder abuse. Fraud may be similar to "fiduciary abuse." However, fiduciary abuse specifically refers to a situation in which a person who has care or custody of the elder takes, secretes, or appropriates their money or property to any use not in the due and lawful execution of his or her trust. Fiduciary abuse also refers to a situation in which an elder requests that a third party transfer to the elder property which belongs to the elder, but that third party fails to take reasonable steps to make the property readily available.

text: You are working with a caseload of homeless men and women at your city's mental health mobile outreach team. Which of the following conditions should you take as the most likely indication of the need for referral to your team's physician for a physical examination?
explanation: Olfactory hallucinations are hallucinations involving the sense of smell. These are commonly caused by organic factors, such as brain tumor or presence of toxic substances in the body. B is incorrect because auditory hallucinations can be caused by organic factors, but are much less likely to be organically caused than are olfactory hallucinations. C is incorrect because excessive guilt is much more likely to be caused by dysfunctional cognitions or psychodynamics such as fixations or unresolved conflicts. D is incorrect because illusions are common. They are not psychotic symptoms and can occur as a result of stress, anxiety, or physical exhaustion.

text: The license of a marriage and family therapist may be revoked if the MFT...
explanation: The Business and Professions Code lists the following a unprofessional conduct for which an MFT license can be revoked or suspended. "Reproduction or description in public, or in any publication subject to general public distribution, of any psychological test or other assessment device, the value of which depends in whole or in part on the naivete of the subject, in ways that might invalidate the test or device? If a client was given a copy of MMPI questions outside of a legitimate administration of that test, the value of the test would be compromised when the test is taken by the client or by anyone with whom the client shares the information. A is incorrect because there is no prohibition against referring clients to another professional, even if the referring party would have been qualified to provide the service. For example, an MFT might refer the husband to a colleague for individual therapy when the MFT is seeing the husband and wife as a couple. C is incorrect because MFT's may provide clients with printed information regarding various aspects of physical health, nutrition, or medication, for example. D is incorrect because there is no requirement that all clients be given written information regarding this matter. The BBS has a publication entitled "Professional Therapy Never Involves Sex" which must be given to any client who indicates that they have been sexually assaulted or harassed by a former therapist, but that is not the situation referenced in answer D.

text: You are working with a caseload of homeless men and women at your city's mental health mobile outreach team. Many of your clients require referrals to your team's physician for medication evaluations. You should make such referrals...
explanation: A is incorrect because clients presenting with mental disorders such as compulsive gambling, adjustment disorders, dependent personality disorder and many others are not particularly in need of medications. C is incorrect because, although medication evaluations should generally be made in cases of major depressive disorder or bipolar disorder, they do not necessarily need to be made in many cases of adjustment disorder with depressed mood or dysthymia. D is incorrect because psychomotor retardation per se does not require medications. It is a symptom that even normal, non-diagnosable individuals might experience when physically exhausted from overwork. Sleep, rest and relaxation are sufficient in most cases without medications.

text: You are working as a member of a multidisciplinary team at a comprehensive health care and psychosocial support program for elders. When making referrals to other professionals either within the program or elsewhere in the community your referral request should....
explanation: By being clear and focused as to the purpose of your referral, the client and the person receiving the referral can approach the matter efficiently and avoid unnecessary role confusion. B is incorrect because such a request would be inefficient. For example, it could lead the physician to evaluate for conditions already known to have been ruled out. C is incorrect because it is inefficient and because the client may not fully understand why the referral is needed. Also, the client may want to raise other issues with the professional receiving the referral, and the professional will need to know which issues are of concern to you and should be reported back to you, and which may be of concern to the client but irrelevant to the client's work with you. D is incorrect because the person receiving the referral does not need to know about your limitations. He or she only needs to know about the client and the client oriented purpose of the referral.

text: You are about to initiate services to a forty-three year old African American woman who has a lifelong problem of moderate depression. She has been ambivalent about seeking therapy for her problem for a variety of reasons. You should expect that this client will be most likely to experience a flight into health during which of the following phases of therapy?
explanation: Flight into health often develops during the first few sessions, in part due to positive transference or magical thinking about the therapist's ability to cause a cure. A is incorrect because the anticipation of termination is more likely to trigger a regression as the client makes a bid to keep the therapeutic relationship going by maintaining a need for it. B is incorrect because just prior to beginning therapy the client is much more likely to be focusing on the problem and his or her inability to solve it without help. D is incorrect because during the middle phase the client's initial fantasies and magical thinking about cure have been dashed through experience. Nothing magical has happened after all. The client may feel disappointed and experience a return of symptoms that have been suppressed, repressed, or otherwise set aside during the initial phase flight into health.

text: You are working with a regressed Chinese American client who is troubled by schizophrenia. The client also has a rich fantasy life and multiple delusions and overvalued ideas. You should choose a therapy approach that...
explanation: A is incorrect because such self-exploration of themes tends to exacerbate internal preoccupation and is likely to be ineffective. B is incorrect because such confrontation is likely to alienate the client and is likely to be ineffective. D is incorrect because, although it may be helpful for the person with schizophrenia to become familiar with the nature of his or her symptoms, the causes of schizophrenia are not yet fully understood by science and will not be of great practical value in the client's daily living. C is a better answer because it is relevant to supporting the client's quality of life, and because medication compliance will probably be the most effective possible approach to reducing the client's multiple delusions and other problematic symptoms.

text: You will be working with an anxious middle aged client who has been troubled by
explanation: Self-alienation refers to a kind of phobic avoidance of parts of ourselves. To the extent that we keep certain needs, feelings, and desires out of awareness we become alienated from ourselves. A part of ourselves is left in the background  our "unfinished business" while we go about tending to the presumably less threatening issues or diversions that we permit into consciousness. Personal integration involves an openness to the full range of our true experience, however unpleasant that may be. The result is personal effectiveness and a more confident sense of presence and integrity. B is incorrect because this describes the general direction of Crisis Intervention Therapy. C is incorrect because Humanistic Existential Psychotherapy moves toward accepting our ambivalences, not overcoming them. The goal is not self certainty and relaxation, but a sense of self acceptance and presence, even in the face of the inevitable self doubts and tensions that arise in our lives. D is incorrect because this is a more apt description of the general direction in Psychodynamic Psychotherapy.

text: When treating minors or adults involved in custody or visitation actions, you...
explanation: This issue is addressed in AAMFT Code of Ethics Sec. 3.14 which states "To avoid a conflict of interests, marriage and family therapists who treat minors or adults involved in custody or visitation actions may not also perform forensic evaluations for custody, residence, or visitation of the minor." A is incorrect because the same section of the Code of Ethics clearly states that the treating marriage and family therapist "may provide the court or mental health professional performing the evaluation with information about the minor from the marriage and family therapist's perspective as a treating marriage and family therapist, so long as the marriage and family therapist does not violate confidentiality." C and D are incorrect because performance of such forensic evaluations is prohibited by the Code of Ethics.

text: You will be helping a rigidly defended 28 year old Latino graduate student reduce the symptoms of an anxiety disorder. You and the client will be working toward restructuring dysfunctional cognitions. Which of the following should you address first?
explanation: Automatic thoughts are more readily apparent to an individual and, therefore, should be addressed first. B is incorrect because core beliefs are deeper cognitions, or fundamental assumptions behind our automatic thoughts. They therefore will take longer to access, if they are to be addressed at all in therapy. C and D are incorrect because "adaptive schemas" and "maladaptive schemas" are types of core beliefs.

text: You and your client will be working toward restructuring dysfunctional cognitions. Your use of the approach known as cognitive empiricism means that you will...
explanation: Cognitive empiricism refers to the collaborative, reality focused way in which the therapist and client function as an investigative team. Hypotheses are developed and their validity is tested through rational analysis and empirical experimentation to discover "does this really make sense?" A is incorrect because it is impossible to refrain from feeling or showing emotion, and because the Cognitive Therapy literature values the use of humor with those clients who respond well to it. C is incorrect because the focus should be on the clients' cognitions here and now, not over time. These present cognitions should be understood in the context of the client's long term growth and development, but most people are unable to clearly remember automatic thoughts from the past. D is incorrect because Cognitive Therapy discourages dependency and regression, while encouraging active participation by the client. This may be done, for example, through the use of self monitoring and self help techniques and homework assignments.

text: You and the client will be working toward restructuring dysfunctional cognitions. In the initial stage of therapy you teach your client to maintain a Daily Record of Dysfunctional Thoughts (DRDT). You should teach the client to keep a record which includes...
explanation: B is incorrect because the DRDT focuses on the individual's own automatic thoughts and his or her own emotional reaction to those thoughts. The DRDT includes a list of circumstances that trigger automatic thoughts, but does not include other people's reactions following the thoughts. Usually, other people don't know when a person is having an automatic thought. C is incorrect because the DRDT includes a list of the client's own more rational, realistic or functional thoughts, not the therapist's. D is incorrect because the only listing of circumstances refers to those that trigger the automatic thought, not those that trigger relaxation or anxiety reduction. That issue is more likely to be addressed in a Behavioral Therapy process of systematic desensitization.

text: You will be working with an anxious adolescent client who has been troubled by a sense of depersonalization and impulse control problems since his family moved to your community from another part of the country. In taking a Humanistic Existential approach to this client you should emphasize a focus on...
explanation: Humanistic Existential Therapies recognize that circumstances influence individuals, but that we each make choices about what we will do with our circumstances. A is incorrect because the focus is on the individuals will and free choice, not on social determinants of one's behavior. The social environment is recognized and understood, but is not the focus of the therapy. B is incorrect because lack of opportunity is one aspect of the social environment. D is incorrect because Humanistic Existential Therapies emphasize experience and self-exploration rather than rational analysis of ones ideas and beliefs. Also, adaptive schemas are a concept drawn from Cognitive Therapy, not in Humanistic Existential Therapy.

text: Your client tells you about a dream in which he was chased by an angry tree through a large mansion. You ask the client to imagine that he is the various parts of his dream....that is, himself, the tree, and the mansion. Your use of this technique should be based on the assumption that...
explanation: Through this technique, primarily associated with Gestalt Therapy, the client engages in self-revelation and self-exploration with the eventual goal of self-integration. A is incorrect because, although playful use of imagination may be adaptive under certain circumstances, it is not the basis for this technique. Also, the use of imagination in this technique is not viewed as inherently healing, but as a means to the end of self-exploration and self-integration. B is incorrect because the holy trinity is a Christian concept which is not accepted by all Humanistic Existential therapists. Although Humanistic Existential Therapies do tend to address spiritual issues, this is usually done in a secular or nonsectarian manner. D is incorrect because taking the role of other dream elements allows us to see ourselves as we truly do at deeper levels of consciousness. It is not designed to allow us to see ourselves as others see us.
